standards.parent_tip: Ask your child to point to the exact sentence that answers a question about the story.

questions.prompt:
Captain Rosie sailed her tiny boat across the lake every morning. One foggy day, she spotted something glowing beneath the water. She leaned over the side and saw a golden chest resting on the sandy bottom.

What did Captain Rosie find under the water?
questions.hint: Look at the last sentence — what was resting on the sandy bottom?

questions.prompt:
Marcus had practiced his speech twenty times. When he stepped onto the stage, his hands were shaking. But once he started talking, the words flowed easily, and the audience clapped loudly at the end.

How did Marcus feel when he first stepped on stage?
questions.hint: The text says his hands were shaking — what feeling does that show?

questions.prompt:
Grandma Chen kept a garden full of herbs. 'Every plant has a story,' she told Mei. She pointed to the lavender. 'Your grandfather brought those seeds from his village.'

Who brought the lavender seeds?
questions.hint: Grandma says 'Your grandfather brought those seeds.' Whose grandfather?

questions.prompt:
The fox crept through the snow, its orange fur bright against the white. It paused, tilted its head, then leaped straight up and dove nose-first into a snowbank. Seconds later, it emerged with a mouse in its jaws.

Why did the fox leap into the snowbank?
questions.hint: What did the fox have when it came back out of the snow?

questions.prompt:
Aisha's violin had belonged to three generations of her family. The wood was worn smooth where countless fingers had pressed the strings. 'Play with your heart, not just your hands,' her mother always said.

What does the worn wood tell us about the violin?
choices: It's been played by many people over many years
questions.correct: It's been played by many people over many years
questions.hint: The text says it belonged to three generations and has smooth, worn wood from countless fingers.

standards.standard_description: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text.

standards.parent_tip: After reading fables or folktales, ask 'What lesson was the author trying to teach?'

questions.prompt:
The crow found a piece of cheese. A fox said, 'What a beautiful voice you must have! Please sing for me.' The crow opened its beak to sing, and the cheese fell right into the fox's mouth.

What is the moral of this fable?
choices: Don't trust flattery from someone who wants something
questions.correct: Don't trust flattery from someone who wants something
questions.hint: The fox used fake compliments to trick the crow. What's the lesson?

questions.prompt:
A boy cried 'Wolf!' when there was no wolf, just to get attention. The villagers came running twice. When a real wolf appeared and the boy cried for help, no one believed him.

What is the central message?
questions.hint: What happened because the boy lied? Nobody believed him when it mattered.

questions.prompt:
King Midas wished that everything he touched would turn to gold. His wish came true! But when his food, his flowers, and even his daughter turned to gold, he begged for the wish to be taken away.

What lesson does this myth teach?
choices: Gold is the most valuable thing
Be careful what you wish for — greed has consequences
questions.correct: Be careful what you wish for — greed has consequences
questions.hint: Midas got exactly what he wanted, but it ruined everything he loved.

questions.prompt:
Two goats met on a narrow bridge over a river. Neither would step aside. They pushed and shoved until both fell into the water below.

What is the lesson?
choices: Stubbornness and refusing to compromise hurts everyone
questions.correct: Stubbornness and refusing to compromise hurts everyone
questions.hint: Neither goat would give way. What happened because of that?

questions.prompt:
A young girl named Anansi's daughter was always bragging about being the smartest in her village. One day, the village elder gave her a riddle she couldn't solve. A quiet boy named Kofi, who listened more than he talked, solved it easily.

What is the central message?
choices: Girls aren't as smart as boys
Bragging doesn't make you smart — listening and thinking do
questions.correct: Bragging doesn't make you smart — listening and thinking do
questions.hint: Compare the girl who bragged with the boy who listened. Who succeeded?

standards.standard_description: Recount stories including fables, folktales, and myths; determine the central message, lesson, or moral.

standards.parent_tip: Ask 'Why did the character do that? What happened because of their choice?'

questions.prompt:
Dina noticed her classmate sitting alone at lunch every day. She walked over and said, 'Want to sit with us?' Soon they became best friends and started a book club together.

What character trait does Dina show?
questions.hint: Dina noticed someone alone and invited them to join. What kind of person does that?

questions.prompt:
When the team's star player got hurt, nobody wanted to take her place. Jaylen was nervous, but he stepped up and said, 'I'll do it.' He scored the winning goal.

How did Jaylen's action affect the story?
choices: His bravery led to the team winning
questions.correct: His bravery led to the team winning
questions.hint: Jaylen volunteered even though he was nervous. What happened because of that?

questions.prompt:
Omar found a wallet on the playground with twenty dollars inside. He thought about keeping it, but instead he brought it to the office. The wallet belonged to a kindergartner's mom.

What does Omar's action tell us about him?
choices: He is scared of getting caught
He is honest and does the right thing
questions.correct: He is honest and does the right thing
questions.hint: Omar chose to return the wallet even though he could have kept the money.

questions.prompt:
Marta refused to share the art supplies with her group. She kept the best markers for herself. The other kids stopped inviting her to work on projects.

What happened BECAUSE of Marta's actions?
questions.hint: Marta's selfishness had a consequence. What was it?

questions.prompt: A character who always makes careful plans before acting can be described as —
questions.hint: Someone who thinks carefully before doing something is being thought-ful!

standards.standard_description: Describe characters in a story and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.

standards.parent_tip: When your child reads phrases like 'raining cats and dogs,' ask 'Does that REALLY mean animals are falling from the sky?'

questions.prompt:
After winning the race, Kenji was on top of the world.

What does 'on top of the world' mean?
choices: He was standing on a globe
questions.hint: This is figurative language — it doesn't literally mean he's on top of the world!

questions.prompt:
'Don't let the cat out of the bag,' whispered Mom before the surprise party.

What does 'let the cat out of the bag' mean?
questions.hint: Mom is talking about keeping the surprise party a secret!

questions.prompt: Which sentence uses LITERAL language?
choices: Time flies when you're having fun.
She has a heart of gold.
questions.hint: Literal language means exactly what it says — no hidden meaning.

questions.prompt:
The classroom was a zoo today!

This means —
choices: They went on a field trip to the zoo
There were animals in the classroom
The classroom was very loud and chaotic
questions.correct: The classroom was very loud and chaotic
questions.hint: The classroom isn't ACTUALLY a zoo — the author is comparing it to one. Why?

questions.prompt:
The icy wind bit at their faces as they walked to school.

What does 'bit at their faces' mean?
choices: The wind felt sharp and painful on their skin
questions.correct: The wind felt sharp and painful on their skin
questions.hint: Wind can't actually bite! The author is describing how the cold FELT.

standards.standard_description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.

standards.parent_tip: Teach your child that chapters are for books, scenes for plays, and stanzas for poems.

questions.prompt: A group of lines in a poem is called a —
questions.hint: Chapters are for books, paragraphs for essays, scenes for plays. What about poems?

questions.prompt: In a play, when the setting or time changes, a new ____ begins.
questions.hint: Plays are divided into acts and these smaller parts.

questions.prompt: A long novel is usually divided into —
questions.hint: Think about how a novel is organized — each section has a number and sometimes a title.

questions.prompt: If a poem has four stanzas, each with four lines, how many lines does the poem have in total?
questions.hint: Four stanzas times four lines each equals...?

questions.prompt: Which text type uses the word 'scene' to describe its parts?
questions.hint: When actors perform on stage, each part of the show is a...?

standards.standard_description: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza.

standards.parent_tip: Ask your child 'Do you agree with what the character did? Would you have done something different?'

questions.prompt:
The narrator says, 'Vegetables are the most boring food in the world.'

This is the point of view of —
questions.hint: Just because a character says something doesn't mean everyone agrees!

questions.prompt: A character in a story thinks it's okay to cheat on a test. You think cheating is wrong. This shows that —
choices: You and the character have different points of view
questions.correct: You and the character have different points of view
questions.hint: It's normal to disagree with a character! That's having a different point of view.

questions.prompt:
I hated moving to a new town. Everything was different and terrible. But by the end of the year, I had the best friends I'd ever had.

Who is telling this story?
questions.hint: The word 'I' tells you this is first-person — the character is telling their own story.

questions.prompt: Why is it important to notice the narrator's point of view?
choices: Because there's only one way to see a story
Because it helps you understand who is telling the story and how they see things
questions.correct: Because it helps you understand who is telling the story and how they see things
questions.hint: Different narrators might tell the same story in very different ways!

questions.prompt:
The wolf in the story said he was just trying to borrow sugar. But the pigs said he tried to blow their houses down.

A reader might think —
choices: The wolf is definitely telling the truth
Both characters have their own version of events, and the reader can decide
questions.correct: Both characters have their own version of events, and the reader can decide
questions.hint: As a reader, YOU get to think about both sides and form your own opinion!

standards.standard_description: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the narrator or those of the characters.

standards.parent_tip: Ask 'What does the picture show that the words don't? How does the picture make you feel?'

questions.prompt: A story says 'The girl walked into the room.' The illustration shows the room decorated with balloons, streamers, and a big cake. The illustration helps show that —
choices: There's a party or celebration happening
questions.correct: There's a party or celebration happening
questions.hint: The words just say she walked in, but the PICTURE adds all those party details!

questions.prompt: An illustration uses dark colors and shadows. This most likely creates a mood that is —
questions.hint: Dark colors and shadows make things feel spooky or tense.

questions.prompt: In a picture book, the text says the character is 'fine.' But the illustration shows tears in the character's eyes. What does the illustration tell us?
choices: The character is lying about their feelings
questions.correct: The character is lying about their feelings
questions.hint: The words say 'fine' but the picture shows tears — those don't match!

questions.prompt: How can an illustration emphasize a character's personality?
choices: By writing the character's name in big letters
By showing the character's clothing, expression, and posture
By using only black and white
questions.correct: By showing the character's clothing, expression, and posture
questions.hint: Think about how someone LOOKS — messy or neat, smiling or frowning, tall and proud or hunched over.

questions.prompt: A story describes a 'small cottage.' The illustration shows it surrounded by enormous trees and a vast mountain range. How does the illustration add to the story?
choices: It shows the cottage is actually big
It emphasizes how small the cottage is compared to nature
questions.correct: It emphasizes how small the cottage is compared to nature
questions.hint: The huge trees and mountains around the tiny cottage show just how small it is!

standards.standard_description: Explain how specific aspects of a text's illustrations contribute to what is conveyed by the words.

standards.parent_tip: If your child reads a book series, ask 'How was this adventure different from the last one?'

questions.prompt: An author writes two books about a character named Max. In Book 1, Max learns to be brave at summer camp. In Book 2, Max learns to be brave at a new school. What is SIMILAR in both books?
questions.hint: Both books are about the same big idea — bravery. That's the theme!

questions.prompt: Two stories by the same author are set in different places — one in a city and one on a farm. But both stories are about friendship. What is DIFFERENT between the stories?
questions.hint: A city and a farm are two different places. That's the setting!

questions.prompt: In Story 1, a girl solves a mystery at her school. In Story 2 by the same author, the same girl solves a mystery at a museum. What changed between the stories?
questions.hint: Same girl, same type of story (mystery), but different place and different mystery!

questions.prompt: Why might an author write multiple books about the same character?
choices: Readers enjoy following a character through new adventures
It's easier to copy the same story
They can't think of new characters
questions.correct: Readers enjoy following a character through new adventures
questions.hint: Think about book series you love — why do you want to read the next one?

questions.prompt: When comparing two stories, which of these would be a CONTRAST (difference)?
choices: Both teach a lesson about kindness
One takes place in winter and the other in summer
Both are written by the same author
Both have the same main character
questions.correct: One takes place in winter and the other in summer
questions.hint: A contrast is something that's DIFFERENT between the two stories.

standards.standard_description: Compare and contrast the themes, settings, and plots of stories written by the same author about the same or similar characters.

standards.parent_tip: Encourage your child to tackle slightly challenging books — that's how reading muscles grow!

questions.prompt:
The old woman lived at the edge of the forest where the trees whispered secrets to one another. Every evening, she placed a lantern in her window. 'For the lost travelers,' she told the cat, who blinked slowly as if he understood.

Why does the old woman place a lantern in her window?
questions.hint: She says it herself — 'For the lost travelers.'

questions.prompt:
Diego had exactly one week to build his invention for the science fair. On Monday he sketched plans. By Wednesday, he'd used all his supplies and started over. On Friday, with tape on his fingers and glue in his hair, he stepped back and grinned.

What can you infer about Diego?
choices: He had help from a friend
He was persistent and creative despite setbacks
He didn't care about the science fair
questions.correct: He was persistent and creative despite setbacks
questions.hint: He started over but kept going. By Friday, he was grinning. What does that tell you?

questions.prompt:
'You can't climb that,' said every kid on the block. Sana looked up at the ancient oak, its branches reaching like outstretched arms. She grabbed the lowest branch and pulled herself up.

The phrase 'branches reaching like outstretched arms' is an example of —
choices: A simile comparing branches to arms
questions.correct: A simile comparing branches to arms
questions.hint: The word 'like' compares two things — branches and outstretched arms.

questions.prompt:
The package sat on the porch for three days. Each morning, Eliot walked past it. Each evening, he wondered what was inside. On the fourth day, he finally picked it up and read the label: 'To Eliot, from your future self.'

What is the author trying to make the reader feel?
questions.hint: A package from your FUTURE self? The author builds mystery to make you want to know more!

questions.prompt:
Everyone said the old house was haunted. Lina didn't believe in ghosts. She marched up the creaky steps, pushed open the door, and found... a family of raccoons living in the fireplace.

What makes this ending effective?
choices: It confirms the house is haunted
It surprises the reader with a funny, unexpected twist
questions.correct: It surprises the reader with a funny, unexpected twist
questions.hint: You expected something spooky, but got raccoons! That surprise is what makes it work.

standards.standard_description: By end of the year, read and comprehend literature at the high end of the grades 2-3 text complexity band.

standards.parent_tip: Ask your child to prove their answer by finding the exact sentence in the text.

questions.prompt:
The Amazon Rainforest produces about 20 percent of the world's oxygen. It is home to more than 10 million species of plants and animals.

How much of the world's oxygen does the Amazon produce?
questions.hint: The percentage is stated in the first sentence.

questions.prompt:
Harriet Tubman escaped slavery in 1849. She then risked her life many times to help others escape through the Underground Railroad. She led about 70 people to freedom.

How many people did Harriet Tubman help escape?
questions.hint: The last sentence gives you the exact number.

questions.prompt:
Earthquakes happen when large pieces of the Earth's crust, called tectonic plates, suddenly move. Most earthquakes occur along the edges of these plates.

What causes earthquakes?
questions.hint: The first sentence explains exactly what causes them.

questions.prompt:
Thomas Edison failed over 1,000 times before successfully inventing the light bulb. He once said, 'I have not failed. I've just found 1,000 ways that won't work.'

What does Edison's quote tell us about his attitude?
choices: He thought 1,000 failures was too many
He was ready to give up
He saw failures as learning experiences
questions.correct: He saw failures as learning experiences
questions.hint: He didn't call them failures — he called them ways that won't work. That's a positive attitude!

questions.prompt:
The International Space Station orbits Earth about every 90 minutes, traveling at 17,500 miles per hour. Astronauts aboard the station see 16 sunrises and sunsets every day.

Why do astronauts see 16 sunrises each day?
choices: The sun moves faster in space
The station orbits Earth so quickly
questions.correct: The station orbits Earth so quickly
questions.hint: It goes around Earth every 90 minutes — so it sees the sun rise and set with each orbit!

standards.standard_description: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text.

standards.parent_tip: Ask 'What is this passage mostly about?' and 'What details help prove that main idea?'

questions.prompt:
Bees are essential to our food supply. They pollinate flowers that grow into fruits and vegetables. Without bees, we would lose about one-third of the food we eat.

What is the main idea?
choices: Bees are important for our food supply
questions.correct: Bees are important for our food supply
questions.hint: The first sentence states the main idea. The rest gives supporting details.

questions.prompt:
Sleep is important for kids. During sleep, your brain stores what you learned that day. Your body grows and repairs itself. Kids who get enough sleep do better in school.

Which detail supports the idea that sleep helps learning?
choices: Your brain stores what you learned
questions.correct: Your brain stores what you learned
questions.hint: Which detail specifically connects sleep to LEARNING?

questions.prompt:
Coral reefs are in danger. Pollution poisons the water. Rising temperatures cause coral to turn white and die. Overfishing removes animals that keep reefs healthy.

The key details all support the main idea that —
questions.hint: Pollution, rising temperatures, overfishing — these are all threats!

questions.prompt: How do you find the main idea of a passage?
choices: Look at the last sentence only
Think about what all the details have in common
questions.correct: Think about what all the details have in common
questions.hint: The main idea is the big umbrella that all the details fit under.

questions.prompt:
Ancient Egyptians invented many things we still use today. They created one of the first writing systems called hieroglyphics. They developed a 365-day calendar. They even invented toothpaste!

What is the main idea?
questions.hint: The passage lists several inventions. What big idea ties them together?

standards.standard_description: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.

standards.parent_tip: Help your child spot signal words like 'because,' 'as a result,' 'first,' 'then,' 'finally.'

questions.prompt:
Because the river flooded, farmers lost their crops. As a result, food prices went up that year.

What caused food prices to go up?
choices: Farmers lost crops due to flooding
questions.correct: Farmers lost crops due to flooding
questions.hint: Follow the chain: flood → lost crops → higher food prices.

questions.prompt:
First, Rosa Parks refused to give up her bus seat in 1955. Then, the Montgomery Bus Boycott began. Finally, the Supreme Court ruled bus segregation was unconstitutional.

Which event happened FIRST?
choices: Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat
questions.correct: Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat
questions.hint: The word 'First' tells you the sequence!

questions.prompt: The words 'because,' 'as a result,' and 'therefore' signal what type of relationship?
questions.hint: These words show that one thing CAUSED another thing to happen.

questions.prompt:
Scientists noticed that temperatures were rising globally. This led to melting ice caps, which caused sea levels to rise.

What is the EFFECT of melting ice caps?
questions.hint: Melting ice caps CAUSED what to happen next?

questions.prompt:
After the Great Fire of London in 1666, the city was rebuilt with stone and brick instead of wood. This made buildings much safer from future fires.

How are these two events connected?
choices: The stone buildings caused the fire
The fire caused the city to change how it built buildings
London stopped building after the fire
questions.correct: The fire caused the city to change how it built buildings
questions.hint: The fire was the cause. Rebuilding with stone was the effect.

standards.standard_description: Describe the relationship between historical events, scientific ideas, or steps in technical procedures using time, sequence, and cause/effect language.

standards.parent_tip: Help your child use context clues and word parts to figure out subject-specific vocabulary.

questions.prompt:
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to make their own food.

What is photosynthesis?
choices: How plants make food using sunlight
questions.correct: How plants make food using sunlight
questions.hint: The sentence defines it right after the word!

questions.prompt:
The Constitution is the supreme law of the United States. It establishes the structure of the government and protects citizens' rights.

What does 'supreme' mean in this context?
questions.hint: The Constitution is the law that all other laws must follow — it's the top one!

questions.prompt:
Erosion is the gradual wearing away of land by water, wind, or ice. Over thousands of years, erosion carved the Grand Canyon.

What does 'gradual' mean?
questions.hint: It took THOUSANDS of years. That's definitely not fast!

questions.prompt:
Herbivores are animals that eat only plants. Deer, rabbits, and cows are all herbivores.

A herbivore eats —
questions.hint: The first sentence tells you the definition right away.

questions.prompt:
The expedition to the South Pole took months of preparation. The team packed food, fuel, and navigation equipment for the dangerous journey.

What is an 'expedition'?
choices: A long journey for a specific purpose
questions.correct: A long journey for a specific purpose
questions.hint: It took months of preparation for a dangerous journey to the South Pole.

standards.standard_description: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text.

standards.parent_tip: Practice using a table of contents, index, headings, and search bars to find information quickly.

questions.prompt: You want to find information about volcanoes on page 47 of a textbook. Which text feature would help you find page 47 the fastest?
questions.hint: The index lists topics alphabetically with page numbers!

questions.prompt: A sidebar in a textbook usually contains —
choices: The main text of the chapter
Extra interesting facts or related information
questions.correct: Extra interesting facts or related information
questions.hint: Sidebars are those boxes on the side of a page with bonus information!

questions.prompt: You're researching dolphins online. Which search term would give you the BEST results?
questions.hint: Specific keywords help you find exactly what you need!

questions.prompt: What is the difference between an index and a glossary?
choices: An index lists topics with page numbers; a glossary defines words
An index is at the front; a glossary is in the middle
An index defines words; a glossary lists page numbers
questions.correct: An index lists topics with page numbers; a glossary defines words
questions.hint: Index = find WHERE something is. Glossary = find WHAT a word means.

questions.prompt: Hyperlinks in a digital text allow you to —
questions.hint: Clicking a hyperlink takes you to another page or section with more information!

standards.standard_description: Use text features and search tools to locate information relevant to a given topic efficiently.

standards.parent_tip: Ask your child 'What does the author think about this topic? Do you agree or disagree?'

questions.prompt:
Homework is valuable because it helps students practice what they learned in class.

The author's point of view is that homework is —
questions.hint: The author uses the word 'valuable' — that tells you they think homework is good.

questions.prompt: A student reads an article that says school should start later. The student likes waking up early. This shows —
choices: The student and author have different points of view
questions.correct: The student and author have different points of view
questions.hint: It's okay to disagree with an author! That's having your own point of view.

questions.prompt: How can you figure out an author's point of view?
choices: Look at the words they choose and what they emphasize
questions.correct: Look at the words they choose and what they emphasize
questions.hint: Authors reveal their opinions through their word choices and what they focus on.

questions.prompt:
Zoos keep animals in small spaces where they can't roam freely. Animals deserve to live in their natural habitats.

The author most likely believes —
choices: Zoos aren't the best place for animals
questions.correct: Zoos aren't the best place for animals
questions.hint: Words like 'small spaces' and 'deserve to live in natural habitats' show the author's opinion.

questions.prompt: Why is it important to recognize your OWN point of view when reading?
choices: So you can think critically and form your own opinions
So you can argue with everyone
So you always agree with the author
questions.correct: So you can think critically and form your own opinions
questions.hint: Good readers don't just accept everything — they think about it and decide for themselves!

standards.standard_description: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the author of a text.

standards.parent_tip: Point out maps, diagrams, and charts in nonfiction — ask what new information they provide.

questions.prompt: A science text describes the water cycle. Beside it is a diagram with arrows showing evaporation, condensation, and precipitation. The diagram helps by —
choices: Showing the process visually so it's easier to understand
questions.correct: Showing the process visually so it's easier to understand
questions.hint: Diagrams show you HOW something works in a way words alone can't.

questions.prompt: A map in a history book shows the route Lewis and Clark traveled. The map helps readers understand —
choices: How far and where they traveled
questions.correct: How far and where they traveled
questions.hint: Maps show locations and distances!

questions.prompt: A photograph in a textbook shows a volcano erupting with lava flowing down its side. The photograph adds to the text by —
choices: Showing what an eruption actually looks like
questions.correct: Showing what an eruption actually looks like
questions.hint: Photos show real-world images that help you picture what the text describes.

questions.prompt: A bar graph in a text about favorite school lunches shows pizza at 45%, tacos at 30%, and salad at 25%. What information does the graph give that the text might not?
choices: The exact percentages at a glance
questions.correct: The exact percentages at a glance
questions.hint: Graphs let you quickly SEE and COMPARE numbers!

questions.prompt: Which illustration would BEST help a reader understand an article about the layers of the Earth?
choices: A cross-section diagram showing the crust, mantle, and core
questions.correct: A cross-section diagram showing the crust, mantle, and core
questions.hint: You can't SEE inside the Earth, so a diagram that shows a cross-section is the best way!

standards.standard_description: Use information from illustrations and the words in a text to demonstrate understanding.

standards.parent_tip: Ask 'Why did the author put this paragraph after that one? How are they connected?'

questions.prompt:
Sentence 1: Plastic bags harm ocean animals. Sentence 2: Sea turtles mistake plastic bags for jellyfish and eat them.

Sentence 2 connects to Sentence 1 by —
choices: Giving an example of how plastic harms animals
questions.correct: Giving an example of how plastic harms animals
questions.hint: Sentence 1 makes a general point. Sentence 2 gives a specific example!

questions.prompt:
Paragraph 1 describes what earthquakes are. Paragraph 2 explains what causes them.

How are these paragraphs connected?
choices: They tell a story in order
The first defines the topic and the second explains the cause
questions.correct: The first defines the topic and the second explains the cause
questions.hint: First you learn WHAT something is, then WHY it happens. That's a logical order!

questions.prompt:
Dogs are loyal pets. However, they require a lot of time and attention.

The word 'however' shows —
questions.hint: 'However' signals that the next idea is different from or opposite to the first.

questions.prompt: A paragraph about saving water is followed by a paragraph listing specific ways to save water at home. The second paragraph —
choices: Provides specific examples to support the first paragraph
questions.correct: Provides specific examples to support the first paragraph
questions.hint: General idea → specific examples. That's a common way paragraphs connect!

questions.prompt: Which signal words show a sequence (order) connection between sentences?
questions.hint: These words tell you the ORDER things happen in!

standards.standard_description: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs in a text.

standards.parent_tip: Read two articles on the same topic and ask your child what each one focused on differently.

questions.prompt: Text A about sharks focuses on how they hunt. Text B about sharks focuses on why they're endangered. What do both texts have in common?
questions.hint: The topic is the same — sharks. But each text focuses on a different aspect.

questions.prompt:
Text A says: "Exercise is important because it keeps your heart healthy." Text B says: "Exercise is important because it improves mood and reduces stress."

What is DIFFERENT between the two texts?
choices: They focus on different BENEFITS of exercise
questions.correct: They focus on different BENEFITS of exercise
questions.hint: Both agree exercise is important — but they highlight different reasons!

questions.prompt: When comparing two texts, which question is MOST useful?
choices: What information is in both, and what is only in one?
questions.correct: What information is in both, and what is only in one?
questions.hint: The best comparison looks at what's shared AND what's unique to each text.

questions.prompt:
Text A: "Mars has the tallest volcano in the solar system." Text B: "Mars once had flowing water on its surface."

These texts provide —
choices: Different facts about the same planet
questions.correct: Different facts about the same planet
questions.hint: Both are about Mars, but each shares a different interesting detail.

questions.prompt: Text A argues that screen time should be limited. Text B argues that educational screen time can be beneficial. A reader should —
choices: Consider both viewpoints and think critically
questions.correct: Consider both viewpoints and think critically
questions.hint: Good readers think about different perspectives before forming their own opinion!

standards.standard_description: Compare and contrast the most important points and key details presented in two texts on the same topic.

standards.parent_tip: Encourage reading nonfiction about topics your child loves — science, animals, history, sports.

questions.prompt:
The Great Barrier Reef stretches over 1,400 miles along Australia's coast. It's so large it can be seen from space. Made up of billions of tiny organisms called coral polyps, it is the largest living structure on Earth.

What are coral polyps?
choices: Tiny organisms that make up the reef
questions.correct: Tiny organisms that make up the reef
questions.hint: The text describes them as 'tiny organisms called coral polyps.'

questions.prompt:
Unlike most spiders, tarantulas don't spin webs to catch prey. Instead, they hunt by ambushing insects and small animals. Despite their scary appearance, most tarantulas are harmless to humans.

What is surprising about tarantulas based on this text?
choices: They are harmless despite looking scary
questions.correct: They are harmless despite looking scary
questions.hint: The word 'despite' signals something unexpected — scary-looking but harmless!

questions.prompt:
In 1928, Alexander Fleming noticed that mold had accidentally grown on one of his petri dishes. The bacteria around the mold had died. This accidental discovery led to the development of penicillin, the world's first antibiotic.

What made Fleming's discovery unusual?
questions.hint: The text uses the word 'accidentally' — Fleming didn't plan this discovery!

questions.prompt:
Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles from Canada to Mexico each fall. No single butterfly makes the entire round trip — it takes multiple generations. The butterflies that fly south in fall are the great-great-grandchildren of the ones that flew north in spring.

Why is the monarch migration remarkable?
choices: Multiple generations complete what no single butterfly could
questions.correct: Multiple generations complete what no single butterfly could
questions.hint: The great-great-grandchildren finish the journey their ancestors started!

questions.prompt:
The Sahara Desert isn't just sand — only about 25% is sandy. The rest includes rocky plateaus, gravel plains, and even mountains. Temperatures can swing from over 130°F during the day to below freezing at night.

What common misconception about the Sahara does this text correct?
questions.hint: The text starts by saying the Sahara ISN'T just sand, then explains what else is there.

standards.standard_description: By end of the year, read and comprehend informational texts at the high end of the grades 2-3 text complexity band.

standards.parent_tip: Encourage your child to break unfamiliar words into familiar parts — prefixes, roots, and suffixes.

questions.prompt: What is the root word in 'uncomfortable'?
questions.hint: Remove the prefix 'un-' and suffix '-able.' What's left?

questions.prompt: How many syllables are in the word 'important'?
questions.hint: Clap it out: im-por-tant. Count the claps!

questions.prompt: Which word has the same 'tion' sound as 'nation'?
questions.hint: Say each word. Which one ends with that 'shun' sound like 'nation'?

questions.prompt: In the word 'knight,' which letters are silent?
questions.hint: Say 'knight' out loud. You hear 'nite' — which letters are you NOT hearing?

questions.prompt: Break the word 'basketball' into syllables:
questions.hint: This compound-style word has three natural breaks.

standards.standard_description: Know and apply grade-level phonics and word analysis skills in decoding words.

standards.parent_tip: Make a prefix/suffix chart: un- = not, re- = again, -ful = full of, -less = without, -ment = act of.

questions.prompt: The prefix 'dis-' in 'disagree' means —
questions.hint: If you disagree, you do NOT agree.

questions.prompt: What does the suffix '-ment' mean in the word 'enjoyment'?
questions.hint: Enjoyment = the act or state of enjoying!

questions.prompt: If 'pre-' means 'before,' what does 'preview' mean?
questions.hint: Pre = before. View = see. So preview = see before!

questions.prompt: Which word uses the suffix '-able' correctly?
questions.hint: '-able' means 'can be done.' Which one sounds right and is a real word?

questions.prompt: The prefix 'mis-' in 'misunderstand' means —
questions.hint: If you misunderstand something, you understand it WRONGLY.

standards.standard_description: Identify and know the meaning of the most common prefixes and derivational suffixes.

standards.parent_tip: Practice Latin suffixes: -tion, -sion, -ible, -able — they appear in many English words!

questions.prompt: What sound does '-tion' make at the end of a word?
questions.hint: Say 'nation' — the '-tion' sounds like 'shun.'

questions.prompt: Which word ends with the '-sion' suffix?
questions.hint: '-sion' also makes the 'shun' sound. Which word has it?

questions.prompt: The suffix '-ible' in 'visible' means —
questions.hint: Visible = able to be seen. So '-ible' means able to be!

questions.prompt: Which word has a Latin suffix?
questions.hint: '-tion' is a Latin suffix commonly found in English words.

questions.prompt: The word 'invention' breaks into which parts?
questions.hint: The root word is 'invent' and the suffix is '-ion.'

standards.standard_description: Decode words with common Latin suffixes.

standards.parent_tip: When your child encounters a long word, have them cover parts and decode one syllable at a time.

questions.prompt: How many syllables are in 'unbelievable'?
questions.hint: Clap it: un-be-liev-a-ble. That's five claps!

questions.prompt: Break 'adventure' into syllables:
questions.hint: Three syllables: ad, ven, ture.

questions.prompt: Which strategy helps you read a long, unfamiliar word?
choices: Guess based on the first letter
Break it into smaller parts and sound out each part
questions.correct: Break it into smaller parts and sound out each part
questions.hint: Chunk the word into syllables, then put the sounds together!

questions.prompt: How many syllables are in 'helicopter'?
questions.hint: Clap it: hel-i-cop-ter.

questions.prompt: Break 'independent' into syllables:
questions.hint: Four syllables: in, de, pen, dent.

standards.standard_description: Decode multisyllable words.

standards.parent_tip: Practice tricky words like 'enough,' 'through,' 'thought' — they don't follow regular phonics rules.

questions.prompt: Which word is spelled correctly?
questions.hint: This tricky word has 'ough' — which doesn't sound like it looks!

questions.prompt: Choose the correct spelling:
questions.hint: Another 'ough' word! Thought has a silent 'gh.'

questions.prompt: The word 'through' rhymes with —
questions.hint: Say 'through' — it sounds like 'threw.' What rhymes with that?

questions.prompt: Which of these words has a silent 'w'?
questions.hint: One of these words has a 'w' you don't actually pronounce!

questions.prompt: Choose the correct spelling of the word that means 'having knowledge':
questions.hint: This word starts with a silent 'k' and has 'ledge' at the end.

standards.standard_description: Read grade-appropriate irregularly spelled words.

standards.parent_tip: Have your child read aloud regularly — encourage smooth, expressive reading at a natural pace.

questions.prompt: What does it mean to read with 'expression'?
choices: Reading every word the same way
Changing your voice to show feelings and meaning
questions.correct: Changing your voice to show feelings and meaning
questions.hint: Expression means your voice shows the emotions in the text!

questions.prompt: A fluent reader —
choices: Reads smoothly and at a natural pace
Reads very slowly, word by word
questions.correct: Reads smoothly and at a natural pace
questions.hint: Fluent reading sounds natural, like a conversation.

questions.prompt: You're reading aloud and you mispronounce a word. What should you do?
choices: Keep going and hope nobody noticed
Go back, correct the word, and reread the sentence
Ask someone to finish for you
questions.correct: Go back, correct the word, and reread the sentence
questions.hint: Good readers self-correct! Go back and fix it.

questions.prompt: How should you read this sentence? "'Watch out!' screamed the lifeguard."
questions.hint: The lifeguard SCREAMED — so read it with urgency!

questions.prompt: Reading accuracy means —
questions.hint: Accuracy = getting the words right!

standards.standard_description: Read with sufficient accuracy and fluency to support comprehension.

standards.parent_tip: Before reading, set a goal: 'Let's read to find out why...' This gives reading a purpose!

questions.prompt:
The octopus is a master of disguise. It can change its color, texture, and even shape to match its surroundings in less than a second.

What makes the octopus a 'master of disguise'?
choices: It can change color, texture, and shape instantly
questions.correct: It can change color, texture, and shape instantly
questions.hint: The second sentence lists all the amazing things it can change!

questions.prompt: Setting a purpose for reading means —
choices: Knowing what you want to learn or find out before you start
questions.correct: Knowing what you want to learn or find out before you start
questions.hint: Having a goal helps you focus and understand better!

questions.prompt:
Benjamin Franklin was not only a Founding Father but also an inventor. He invented bifocal glasses, the lightning rod, and a more efficient fireplace called the Franklin stove.

What were three of Franklin's inventions?
choices: Bifocals, lightning rod, and Franklin stove
The telephone, light bulb, and car
The Constitution, the flag, and the dollar
questions.correct: Bifocals, lightning rod, and Franklin stove
questions.hint: The second sentence lists his three inventions.

questions.prompt:
Unlike most fish, seahorses swim upright and are surprisingly slow swimmers. The dwarf seahorse holds the record as the slowest fish in the ocean, moving at just 5 feet per hour.

What is unusual about how seahorses swim?
choices: They swim upright instead of horizontally
questions.correct: They swim upright instead of horizontally
questions.hint: The text says 'unlike most fish' — what do seahorses do differently?

questions.prompt: After reading a passage, what should you be able to do?
choices: Draw a perfect picture of it
Explain the main idea and key details in your own words
questions.correct: Explain the main idea and key details in your own words
questions.hint: Understanding means you can talk about what you read in your own words!

standards.standard_description: Read grade-level text with purpose and understanding.

standards.parent_tip: Practice reading aloud together — take turns with different characters and use expressive voices!

questions.prompt: When reading a poem aloud, you should —
choices: Pay attention to rhythm and pause at line breaks
questions.correct: Pay attention to rhythm and pause at line breaks
questions.hint: Poems have a special rhythm — reading them well means following that beat!

questions.prompt: How should you read this line? "'Please,' she begged quietly, 'don't go.'"
questions.hint: She 'begged quietly' — match your voice to that!

questions.prompt: What does 'appropriate rate' mean when reading aloud?
choices: So slow every word takes 5 seconds
At a constant speed with no changes
At a speed that sounds natural and allows understanding
questions.correct: At a speed that sounds natural and allows understanding
questions.hint: Not too fast, not too slow — like how you'd tell a friend a story.

questions.prompt: A passage has a tense, exciting action scene. How should your reading change?
choices: Speed up slightly and add energy to your voice
questions.correct: Speed up slightly and add energy to your voice
questions.hint: Match the energy of the scene — exciting moments need exciting reading!

questions.prompt: When reading dialogue between two characters, what should you do?
choices: Use a slightly different voice for each character
Read both characters the same way
questions.correct: Use a slightly different voice for each character
questions.hint: Different voices help listeners know which character is speaking!

standards.standard_description: Read grade-level prose and poetry orally with accuracy, appropriate rate, and expression.

standards.parent_tip: When your child reads something that doesn't make sense, encourage them to reread and try again.

questions.prompt: You read the word 'desert' as 'dessert' in this sentence: 'The camel walked across the hot desert.' How do you know you made a mistake?
choices: Dessert doesn't make sense in a sentence about camels and heat
The sentence has too many words
questions.correct: Dessert doesn't make sense in a sentence about camels and heat
questions.hint: Camels don't walk across dessert! The context tells you the word should be 'desert.'

questions.prompt: What is 'self-correcting' when reading?
choices: You notice your own mistake and fix it
questions.correct: You notice your own mistake and fix it
questions.hint: 'Self' means you do it yourself. 'Correcting' means fixing!

questions.prompt: 'The scientist used a microscope to examine the tiny ____.' Which word fits best?
questions.hint: A microscope looks at TINY things. Which answer is something tiny a scientist would study?

questions.prompt: If you read a paragraph and it doesn't make sense, the BEST thing to do is —
choices: Move on to the next chapter
questions.hint: Slowing down and rereading helps you catch what you missed!

questions.prompt: You read 'wind' as rhyming with 'find' in this sentence: 'The wind blew the leaves across the yard.' Is that correct?
choices: You can't tell from the sentence
No, in this sentence 'wind' rhymes with 'pinned'
questions.correct: No, in this sentence 'wind' rhymes with 'pinned'
questions.hint: Context clue: wind that BLOWS is pronounced like 'pinned,' not like 'find.'

standards.standard_description: Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, rereading as necessary.

standards.parent_tip: Teach your child to use context clues, word parts, and dictionaries to unlock new words.

questions.prompt:
The spectators cheered wildly as the runner crossed the finish line.

What are 'spectators'?
questions.hint: Spectators were cheering — they were watching the race, not running it!

questions.prompt:
The word 'light' can mean many things. What does it mean here?

"Please light the candle."
questions.hint: You 'light' a candle by giving it a flame.

questions.prompt:
The magician performed an elaborate trick with scarves, rings, and hidden mirrors.

What does 'elaborate' mean?
questions.hint: The trick used scarves, rings, AND hidden mirrors — that's not simple!

questions.prompt:
What does 'current' mean in this sentence?

"The strong current carried the boat downstream."
questions.hint: A current in a river is the moving water that can carry things downstream.

questions.prompt:
After the long drought, the parched earth cracked and split.

What does 'parched' mean?
questions.hint: A drought means no rain. If the earth is cracking, it must be very dry!

standards.standard_description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases.

standards.parent_tip: When your child hits an unknown word, say 'Read the whole sentence — what clues help you figure it out?'

questions.prompt:
The benevolent king gave food to every poor family in his kingdom.

What does 'benevolent' most likely mean?
questions.hint: A king who gives food to poor families sounds kind and generous!

questions.prompt:
The abandoned house was empty, with broken windows and weeds growing through the porch.

What does 'abandoned' mean?
questions.hint: Empty, broken windows, weeds — nobody lives there anymore!

questions.prompt:
The camouflaged lizard blended perfectly with the brown leaves on the ground.

What does 'camouflaged' mean?
questions.hint: It 'blended perfectly' — camouflage means hiding by looking like your surroundings.

questions.prompt:
The fragile vase shattered into a hundred pieces when it hit the floor.

What does 'fragile' mean?
questions.hint: It shattered into pieces — so it must break easily!

questions.prompt:
The nocturnal owl hunted mice while other birds slept.

Using context clues, 'nocturnal' means —
questions.hint: The owl hunted while other birds SLEPT. When do birds sleep? At night!

standards.standard_description: Use sentence-level context as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

standards.parent_tip: Practice: 'If agree means to think the same, what does disagree mean? What about agreeable?'

questions.prompt: If 'comfort' means a state of ease, what does 'uncomfortable' mean?
questions.hint: 'Un-' means not. So un + comfortable = not comfortable.

questions.prompt: What does 'misspell' mean?
questions.hint: 'Mis-' means wrongly. Mis + spell = spell wrongly!

questions.prompt: The word 'impossible' means —
questions.hint: 'Im-' (like 'in-') means not. Impossible = not possible.

questions.prompt: If 'courage' means bravery, what does 'encourage' mean?
choices: To give courage or support to someone
questions.correct: To give courage or support to someone
questions.hint: 'En-' means to put into. Encourage = put courage INTO someone!

questions.prompt: What does 'disappearance' mean?
questions.hint: Dis + appear + ance. 'Dis-' means opposite, '-ance' means the act of.

standards.standard_description: Determine the meaning of the new word formed when a known affix is added to a known word.

standards.parent_tip: Show your child how 'sign' connects to 'signal,' 'signature,' and 'design.'

questions.prompt: If 'act' means to do something, what does 'action' mean?
questions.hint: Act + ion. The root 'act' means to do, and '-ion' makes it a noun.

questions.prompt: The root word 'port' means 'to carry.' What does 'transport' most likely mean?
choices: To carry across or from one place to another
questions.correct: To carry across or from one place to another
questions.hint: 'Trans' means across. 'Port' means carry. Transport = carry across!

questions.prompt: You know 'graph' means 'to write or draw.' Which word is related to writing or drawing?
questions.hint: Photo = light. Graph = write/draw. A photograph is written with light!

questions.prompt: If 'cycle' means 'circle' or 'wheel,' what does 'bicycle' mean?
questions.hint: 'Bi' means two. 'Cycle' means wheel. Bicycle = two wheels!

questions.prompt: The words 'company' and 'companion' share the root 'compan-' which means 'together with bread.' Both words relate to —
questions.hint: Sharing bread = being together. Both words are about togetherness!

standards.standard_description: Use a known root word as a clue to the meaning of an unknown word with the same root.

standards.parent_tip: Practice dictionary skills — guide words, alphabetical order, multiple definitions.

questions.prompt:
A dictionary entry for 'bark' shows two definitions: 1. The outer covering of a tree. 2. The sound a dog makes. How do you know which definition fits?

"The bark of the old oak tree was rough and gray."
questions.hint: It's describing a tree, so it's the outer covering — definition 1!

questions.prompt: Guide words at the top of a dictionary page are 'maple' and 'market.' Which word would be on this page?
questions.hint: The word must come between 'maple' and 'market' alphabetically.

questions.prompt: What information does a dictionary give you about a word?
choices: Spelling, pronunciation, definition, and part of speech
questions.correct: Spelling, pronunciation, definition, and part of speech
questions.hint: A dictionary is packed with info — spelling, how to say it, what it means, and how to use it!

questions.prompt: In a glossary, you find: 'ecosystem (n.) — a community of living things and their environment.' The '(n.)' tells you that 'ecosystem' is a —
questions.hint: The abbreviation 'n.' stands for noun!

questions.prompt: When is it BEST to use a dictionary or glossary?
choices: When context clues and word parts don't help enough
When you already know the word
questions.correct: When context clues and word parts don't help enough
questions.hint: Try context clues first, then word parts. If you're still stuck, grab the dictionary!

standards.standard_description: Use glossaries or beginning dictionaries to determine or clarify the precise meaning of key words.

standards.parent_tip: Point out figurative language in everyday life: 'It's raining cats and dogs!' means it's raining very hard.

questions.prompt:
She had a heart of gold.

This means —
choices: She was very kind and generous
Her heart was made of gold metal
questions.correct: She was very kind and generous
questions.hint: This is figurative language — a 'heart of gold' means a person who is very kind.

questions.prompt: Which sentence uses a simile?
choices: She was as fast as a rocket.
questions.correct: She was as fast as a rocket.
questions.hint: A simile compares two things using 'as' or 'like.'

questions.prompt: What does 'break a leg' mean?
questions.hint: This is an idiom — it means the opposite of what it sounds like! Performers say it for luck.

questions.prompt: Which two words are antonyms (opposites)?
questions.hint: Antonyms are opposites. Which pair shows opposite meanings?

questions.prompt:
The thunder grumbled like an angry old man.

This is an example of —
questions.hint: Thunder 'grumbling' is personification (human action). 'Like an angry old man' is a simile!

standards.standard_description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

standards.parent_tip: Ask 'Does this sentence mean exactly what it says, or is it saying something in a creative way?'

questions.prompt:
Time flies when you're having fun.

Is this literal or nonliteral?
choices: Nonliteral — it means time seems to pass quickly
questions.correct: Nonliteral — it means time seems to pass quickly
questions.hint: Time doesn't actually fly! It's a figurative way of saying time SEEMS to go fast.

questions.prompt: Which sentence is LITERAL (means exactly what it says)?
choices: The cat sat on the mat.
She has butterflies in her stomach.
questions.correct: The cat sat on the mat.
questions.hint: Only one of these sentences describes something that could actually, physically happen.

questions.prompt:
My backpack weighs a ton.

What does this really mean?
choices: The backpack is made of metal
questions.hint: A backpack can't really weigh a ton! This is an exaggeration (hyperbole).

questions.prompt:
She was drowning in homework.

This means —
choices: She fell into a pool of papers
She had way too much homework
questions.correct: She had way too much homework
questions.hint: You can't literally drown in homework! It means she had an overwhelming amount.

questions.prompt:
His words cut like a knife.

This sentence means his words were —
questions.hint: Words can't actually cut, but they CAN hurt feelings — like a knife hurts physically.

standards.standard_description: Distinguish the literal and nonliteral meanings of words and phrases in context.

standards.parent_tip: Connect vocabulary to real experiences: 'When have YOU felt courageous? What made it brave?'

questions.prompt: When would you describe someone as 'generous'?
choices: When they keep everything for themselves
When they share with others willingly
questions.correct: When they share with others willingly
questions.hint: Generous means giving freely. Think of someone who shares!

questions.prompt: Which situation shows 'cooperation'?
choices: A student working alone on a test
A group building a fort together
questions.correct: A group building a fort together
questions.hint: Cooperation means working together. Which choice shows teamwork?

questions.prompt: Which word BEST describes how you feel when you try something new and scary?
questions.hint: Trying something new and scary can make you feel nervous or anxious.

questions.prompt: A person who always tells the truth can be described as —
questions.hint: Someone truthful is honest — a word connected to trust.

questions.prompt: Which word describes a person who keeps trying even when things are difficult?
questions.hint: Think of someone who doesn't give up. They per-sist!

standards.standard_description: Identify real-life connections between words and their use.

standards.parent_tip: Play 'word ladders' — arrange words by intensity: annoyed → angry → furious.

questions.prompt: Put these words in order from LEAST certain to MOST certain: knew, suspected, wondered
questions.hint: Wondering is just curious. Suspecting is thinking it might be true. Knowing is being certain!

questions.prompt: Which word shows the STRONGEST feeling of anger?
questions.hint: All these words relate to anger, but which one is the most intense?

questions.prompt: Put these in order from LEAST scared to MOST scared: terrified, nervous, uneasy
questions.hint: Uneasy is mild, nervous is moderate, terrified is extreme fear!

questions.prompt: Which word means MORE than 'happy' but LESS than 'ecstatic'?
questions.hint: Happy → delighted → ecstatic. Delighted is in the middle!

questions.prompt:
I heard the rumor about the snow day." vs. "I knew school would be canceled.

Which shows MORE certainty?
questions.hint: Hearing something is secondhand information. Knowing is being sure!

standards.standard_description: Distinguish shades of meaning among related words that describe states of mind or degrees of certainty.

standards.parent_tip: Encourage your child to use precise words: instead of 'nice,' try 'generous,' 'thoughtful,' or 'delightful.'

questions.prompt: Which sentence uses more precise vocabulary?
choices: The pasta was delicious and perfectly seasoned.
questions.correct: The pasta was delicious and perfectly seasoned.
questions.hint: Precise words paint a clearer picture. Which sentence tells you the MOST?

questions.prompt: In science, 'habitat' means —
choices: The natural home of an animal or plant
questions.correct: The natural home of an animal or plant
questions.hint: This is a domain-specific word used in science to describe where organisms live.

questions.prompt:
Which word is a better replacement for 'said' in this sentence?

"'I can't believe it!' ____ Maria."
questions.hint: She can't believe it! That shows surprise and excitement. Which word matches that energy?

questions.prompt: The academic word 'compare' means to —
choices: Find how things are alike and different
questions.correct: Find how things are alike and different
questions.hint: 'Compare' is a word you use in all subjects — it means looking at similarities and differences.

questions.prompt:
Choose the MOST specific word to complete this sentence:

"The ____ cheetah sprinted across the savanna."
questions.hint: All could work, but 'swift' is the most vivid and precise for describing a cheetah's speed.

standards.standard_description: Acquire and use accurately conversational, general academic, and domain-specific words and phrases.
